events.description: Release of January inflation data for the eurozone showing a cooling trend.
The European Central Bank's scheduled policy announcement on Thursday.
Germany's plan to raise a record amount of debt in the current year.

facts.fact_text: January CPI in the eurozone eased to 1.7%.

evidences.evidence_text: January’s CPI eased to 1.7%, well below the ECB’s target

facts.fact_text: Core inflation in the eurozone fell to 2.2%.

evidences.evidence_text: core inflation unexpectedly fell to 2.2%, its lowest level since October 2021

facts.fact_text: Germany plans to raise €512 billion in debt this year.

evidences.evidence_text: Germany plans to raise a record €512 billion this year to fund infrastructure projects and boost defense spending

claims.claim_text: The ECB is expected to keep interest rates unchanged for the fifth consecutive meeting.
claims.author: Market consensus

evidences.evidence_text: widely expected to keep rates on hold for a fifth consecutive meeting

claims.claim_text: Christine Lagarde will likely state that current policy is appropriate.
claims.author: Market analysts

evidences.evidence_text: ECB President Christine Lagarde is expected to reiterate that policy remains in a “good place”

claims.claim_text: Markets are pricing in stable interest rates until 2026.
claims.author: Markets

evidences.evidence_text: markets pricing in steady rates through 2026

claims.claim_text: Rapid euro appreciation is causing concern among ECB policymakers.
claims.author: Policymakers

evidences.evidence_text: raising concerns among policymakers about the euro’s rapid appreciation

evidence.evidence_text: Germany’s 10-year Bund yield dipped to 2.87% as investors absorbed signs of slowing inflation across the eurozone
Bund yields remain near the March 2025 peak just above 2.9%, supported by a surge in debt issuance
raising concerns among policymakers about the euro’s rapid appreciation and the potential resumption of rate cuts
